search_results.title: Rät
search_results.lyrics:
Rät Lyrics[Verse 1]
I come from scientists and atheists and white men who kill God
They make technology, high quality, complex physiological
Experiments and sacrilege in the name of public good
They taught me everything, just like a daddy should
And you were beautiful and vulnerable and power and success
God damn, I fell for you, your flamethrowers, your tunnels and your tech
I studied code because I wanted to do something great like you
And the real tragеdy is half of it was true

[Pre-Chorus 1]
But we've been fuckin' mеan, we're elitist, we're as flawed as any church
And this faux-rad West coast dogma has a higher fuckin' net worth
I bit the apple 'cause I trusted you, it tastes like Thomas Malthus
Your proposal is immodest and insane
And I hope someday Selmers rides her fuckin' train
[Chorus]
I loved you, I loved you, I loved you, it's true
I wanted to be you and do what you do
I lived here, I loved here, I thought it was true
I feel so stupid, and so used
I feel so used

[Verse 2]
I was your baby, your firstborn, the hot girl in your comp-sci class
And I was Darwin's prep school dream, bred, born and raised to kick your ass
I fell for circuit boards, rocket ships, pictures of the stars
If you could only be what you pretend you are
When I said take me to the moon, I never meant take me alone
I thought if mankind toured the sky, it meant that all of us could go
But I don't want to see the stars if they're just one more piece of land
For us to colonize, for us to turn to sand

[Pre-Chorus 2]
'Cause we're so fuckin' mean, we're so elitist, we're as fucked as any church
And this bullshit West coast dogma has a higher fuckin' net worth
I bit the apple 'cause I loved you, and why would you lie?
And then I realized you're just as naïve as I am
Oh, you're so traumatized, it makes me want to cry

[Chorus]
You dumb bitch
I loved you, I loved you, I loved you, it's true
I wanted to be you and do what you do
I lived here, I loved here, I bought it, it's true
I'm so embarrassed, I feel abused
You might also like[Verse 3]
Well, I don't want to eat the rich, I'd have to eat my heroes first
And my tuition's paid by blood, I might deserve your fate or worse
But I don't need your god damn money, I don't need jack shit from you
So when I speak, you bet your life my words are true
Let me level with you, man, as someone guilty of the game
I took the help, I took the cash, I would've taken your last name
So if any girl on Earth should get to make a call about this
It should be me, and as I see it, you're a dick

[Pre-Chorus 3]
So fuck your tunnels, fuck your cars, fuck your rockets, fuck your cars again
You promised you'd be Tesla, but you're just another Edison
'Cause Tesla broke a patent, all you ever broke were hearts
I can't believe you tore humanity apart
With the very same machines that could have been our brand new start

[Chorus]
And the worst part is
I loved you, I loved you, I loved you, it's true
And sometimes I feel like I still fuckin' do
I lived here, I loved here, I bought it, it's true
I'm so embarrassed, I feel abused
I feel so used
I feel so used
Take me to the moon
'Cause I feel so used
I feel so used123Embed

description.plain:
Described as “a breakup letter to the tech cult that is Silicon Valley,” this song was originally called “Elongated Muskrat” as a reference to Elon Musk.
Scott describes how, like many other Gen Z kids, she looked up to scientists and Silicon Valley, and looked down on religion. She explores the idea of conflicting views on modern wealth, of hating the rich, yet idolizing them at the same time.

Scott debuted a rough acoustic version of the song on TikTok:
https://www.tiktok.com/@worsethanithot/video/6851803905555205381?source=h5_m&lang=en

song.embed_content: Read “Rät” by Penelope Scott on Genius
song.title: Rät

body.plain:
Described as “a breakup letter to the tech cult that is Silicon Valley,” this song was originally called “Elongated Muskrat” as a reference to Elon Musk.
Scott describes how, like many other Gen Z kids, she looked up to scientists and Silicon Valley, and looked down on religion. She explores the idea of conflicting views on modern wealth, of hating the rich, yet idolizing them at the same time.

Scott debuted a rough acoustic version of the song on TikTok:
https://www.tiktok.com/@worsethanithot/video/6851803905555205381?source=h5_m&lang=en

annotations: Make technology, high quality, complex physiological
Sorry meant to highlight the whole line
They
Technology and science often contradict the Bible, such as the evolution of life and god creating it in a week.
You dumb bitch
she could be calling the abstract entity of Silicon Valley a “dumb bitch” as a blanket insult, or insulting herself for being as naïve as to fall for them
Oh, you’re so traumatized, it makes me want to cry

About this line, Scott told Genius,

You will often get to a point with an adult that you trust, where you say, ‘Well, why don’t we just do it this way?’ and they say, ‘You don’t know what you’re talking about.  You’re naive.  You don’t understand.  If you had just lived in this society as long as I’ve lived in this society, you’d understand why it has to be this fucked up.’  That’s trauma.  That’s pretty clearly trauma, the idea that there’s a thing that’s  clearly right, and you’re so scared to do it ‘cause you’ve never lived in a place where it’s possible, is traumatic.
I feel so stupid, and so used

This is a sentiment Penelope repeats throughout this song, this being the first time she says it. She feels used because she looked up to many scientific and technological innovators growing up that aren’t great people, just like many Gen Z kids. They blindly followed and the spread the ideas of people due to their innovations when in actuality they are twisted by capitalism in many ways and hurt a lot of people.
Experiments and sacrilege in the name of public good

Since sacrilege is defined as, “Violation or misuse of what is regarded as sacred,” this is an interesting charge to level against a group of atheists.

Most likely, this is implying that would-be secular humanists like Musk are neglecting the humanism that they claim justifies both their rejection of religion and the technological revolution they promote.

Calling this value of sacrifice “in the name of public good” sacred implies an ironic connection between the atheistic “cult of technology” and the traditional religions that it claims to reject.  This idea recurs throughout the song, for example in the pre-chorus line,

We’re as flawed as any church

So if any girl on Earth should get to make a call about this
 It should be me, and as I see it, you’re a dick

She knows that she is also “guilty of the game” (the game referring to, as previously stated, economic privilege), so seeing Musk and other people she looked at as her idols “play the game,” upsets her.

This may be a stretch, but because she knows the game, was able to escape the loop, and no longer plays said game, seeing all these other people not making an effort to stop the process she’s disappointed in them and no longer supports them.
They taught me everything, just like a daddy should

Here, “daddy” likely refers to the “white men” mentioned in the first line, who have trained or “raised” the speaker to eschew religious belief in favor of uncompromising rationalism.

Traditional religions often frame their authority in terms of father figures, calling priests “father” or referring to “God the father,” for example.  However, the line drips with irony, as the influence of the rationalist tradition that claims to foster independent thought is portrayed as paternalistic and dogmatic in itself.
I come from scientists and atheists and white men who kill God

The speaker is introduced with a reference to an idea most often attributed to the famous dead, white man Friedrich Nietzsche, the notion that “God is dead.”

Rather than posit the literal death of any deity, this statement asserts that the Scientific Revolution started during the Enlightenment has irrevocably put Western civilization on a path toward shedding religious belief by “killing” our need for the idea of God to understand ourselves and our world.

In the song, the line frames this idea as formative to the speaker’s perspective, but also suggests that it might be problematic, and possibly related to Western, male oppression.
And then I realized you’re just as naïve as I am

This is referencing the vicious cycle of “dying a hero or living long enough to become the villain”. She’s saying that Elon Musk was just as much of a dreamer as she was; that he failed to recognize the flaws of the people he worships and has instead become them. Scott is wise enough to realize that although she resents Musk for the values he’s perpetuated, it’s not a problem that started with him. She also mentions this phenomenon in another song on this album, “Moonsickness”:

And it’s not all you, man
You were just a kid once

description.plain:
“Lotta True Crime” is about the rising interest in true crime by women and the idea that serial killers are over-glorified in the media. As with many of Scott’s songs, the lyrics are often satirical and spiteful in nature.

Lotta True Crime is second song on Penelope Scott’s album, “Public Void.”

body.plain:
“Lotta True Crime” is about the rising interest in true crime by women and the idea that serial killers are over-glorified in the media. As with many of Scott’s songs, the lyrics are often satirical and spiteful in nature.

Lotta True Crime is second song on Penelope Scott’s album, “Public Void.”

songs.full_title: Papayawhip (God or whatever) by Penelope Scott
songs.title: Papayawhip (God or whatever)

annotations: [Bridge]
This section was originally from another of Penelope Scott’s songs Papayawhip(god or whatever)
And I like ’em at night
Many people avoid scary stories at night as they seem scarier in the dark. This is the narrator saying these stories don’t scare her, or she doesn’t care, even at night.
Well I hope this doesn’t seem too impolite
This is intentionally ironic because, yknow, murdering innocent women is quite impolite.

Shaking, quaking, terrified that one day, somehow, someway
 They might meet me.”

It’s possible that Scott thinks/copes that it’s very likely for a woman to win a fight against armed men, while she herself is only armed with a key between her finger

It’s actually very unlikely for this, but as Scott states, she would strike a fear in these two murderers.

But it’s alright, she’ll be fine
 We listen to a lotta True Crime

Scott is talking as much to herself as the listener. Like many people, she wants to believe that preparation can save a potential victim from a crime, or at least mitigate the effects. This doesn’t happen (as shown in the image of the woman in the first verse who was unable to overcome her adversary), but she continues to believe it.
Somebody new must’ve gone bad
Killing/crime happens often, such that people immediately associate it with a new serial killer appearing.
Cause there was no fuckin’ candle in his pumpkin head
Scott said this because he wasn’t as smart as people might think. She was talking about how he never really had the knowledge to help his case.
But he’s ugly, and I’m glad he’s dead

This is in response to the many people who claim Ted Bundy was able to get away with his crimes for so long due to his attractive looks. During his trial, several women thought that Bundy was charismatic and handsome and was incapable of committing such acts of violence.

Scott is retaliating against this, calling him ugly and reaffirming the idea that he was a monster who deserved to die.

I like the girl talk vibes
 They make me feel just fine
 I listen to a lotta True Crime

The “girl talk vibes” is in reference to the many true crime podcasts hosted by women that take a more casual approach to researching violent cases. In a way, this lighthearted attitude normalizes the idea of what could happen and how to protect oneself in the event that the worst case scenario occurs.

This sort of “preparation” for the worst is what drives the speaker to believe she can take on a killer and walk away victorious.

She could’ve killed you, she had every right
 You just caught her off guard tonight

The facade of the powerful woman who defeated her adversary is broken for a brief moment and we see that the girl mentioned in the first verse was not able to save herself from her fate. Scott maintains, however, that she could have beat him any other night, the killer simply got lucky.

[Verse 3]

And we drank it to go out or just stay in or to feel sad
But in a hot way, a way I'll fuckin' never have again
The sun has began to set
I'm a socialist, Marxist, libertarian slut
I am an awkward teenage virgin and I sort of kinda laugh a lot in bed
But other times, I cry or don't make noise at all
I'd give my life to have a room that feels that small

[Chorus]
'Cause someone loved me, someone fucking loved me
Someone fucking loved me, I loved them too
Goddamn it, I was worth something, I fuckin' earned something
I had a right to die, a right to live, a right to choose, too
And God, no!
Of course, I don't wanna feel better!

You might also like[Post-Chorus]
No one's ever gonna love me like that again
I don't wanna get over it, I wanna rip the stars to shreds

[Verse 4]
Of course it hurt, of course it fuckin' hurt
It hurt like nothing in the world sometimes

[Bridge]

Goddamn it, I was worth something, I fuckin' learned something
And it felt better in my mouth than fresh warm food
I guess I loved you, I guess I really loved you
All my filthy life I loved someone I barely knew
And now you're over there and I'm way over here
What am I gonna do?
[Outro]
I don't wanna feel better
No one's ever gonna love me like that again
I don't wanna get over you
I wanna sit with you in bed
I don't wanna feel better
(I don't wanna feel better)17Embed

description.plain:
Feel Better is the third song on “Goblin Hours” and is also featured as the fourth track on “Public Void.” It can be listened to on Penelope Scott’s Bandcamp

Goblin Hours by Penelope Scott


On Bandcamp, Penelope writes “Summer was hard on us all,” suggesting that this song was a response/story of something that happened during the summer.

song.title: Feel Better

body.plain:
Feel Better is the third song on “Goblin Hours” and is also featured as the fourth track on “Public Void.” It can be listened to on Penelope Scott’s Bandcamp

Goblin Hours by Penelope Scott


On Bandcamp, Penelope writes “Summer was hard on us all,” suggesting that this song was a response/story of something that happened during the summer.

annotations:
No one’s ever gonna love me like that again
 I don’t wanna get over it, I wanna rip the stars to shreds
Because of the breakup, she feels hopeless because she isn’t receiving love anymore. She’s angry about it, showing her anger as ripping the stars up.

I don’t wanna get over you
 I wanna sit with you in bed
The singer is saying that she doesn’t want to get over her ex, but instead she wants to continue being with the person.

I am an awkward teenage virgin and I sort of kinda laugh a lot in bed
 But other times, I cry or don’t make noise at all

I think this is a hint that Penelope is not really missing what she got out of the relationship so much as just the fact that being in a relationship made her feel loved and like she had self worth, or that possibly some things had happened in the relationship that really changed her in a negative way, going from an “awkward teenage virgin” who laughs in bed (pretty clearly a past version of herself since Penelope is 21 and implies she and this lover slept together by her repeated references to being in bed with them) to crying or feeling nothing in bed. It raises the possibility to me at least that this relationship may not have been a healthy, happy one or may have been extremely unstable before ending but that Penelope struggles with moving on from it bc she doesn’t love herself and without the reminder that someone else loves her at least enough to stay with her she feels lost and worthless. This ties into her previous line about being “really fucking selfish, and really fucking lost”; she knows this wasn’t good for her or her lover, but wanted to cling to it bc she based her whole worth on it. It actually reminds me a lot of my own experiences with a relationship that was emotionally supportive but physically and sexually abusive, where I allowed myself to be scarred and mistreated bc my self esteem was so bad and my need for an emotional outlet was so great I was terrified of being left by someone who hurt me and made me miserable but lovebombed the hell out of me… particularly bc “feeling nothing in bed” both physically and emotionally is a coping mechanism that a lot of people, myself included, use to survive sexual trauma and can make it extremely difficult to move on and find happiness alone or with a new lover. You feel like a part of you is completely broken and like you’ll never experience the joy sex brought you before the trauma, or be able to really give your full self to another lover again.

And someone’s breaking up when I crack up
 Because I know I’ll never know just what to say

I believe this line describes the feeling of knowing there’s no right or wrong thing to say while trying to console someone after a breakup, and cracking up (laughing) at your efforts, because nothing you’ll say is enough.
Or I’m a sad girl in a dorm room, living out the shady Christian plot of
Here, she contrasts her online persona, which is very political and often revered for her cynical lyrics, and how she sees herself, as just another ‘sad girl’.
All my filthy life I loved someone I barely knew
This may hint that the ex had a side that they hid from singer, thus making them feel like they never knew their lover at all.
And now you’re over there and I’m way over here

This is about how her and her former lover are on very different paths. The singer has obviously taken it worse than her former lover, also talking about depression and missing them. “Now You’re over there” could also mean that her ex has found a new lover and is in a very different state than when they were with the singer.
I might’ve died there twice and I would do it all again

People willingly return to abusive relationships often knowing the pain (near death in this verse) they have experienced for many reasons (https://offices.depaul.edu/student-affairs/support-services/health-wellness/sexual-relationship-violence-prevention/Documents/Why_Do_People_Stay_In_Abusive_Relationships.pdf).
All my filthy life I loved someone I barely knew

Sometimes after you break up with someone or just get separated from someone you love platonically or romantically maybe ending up with them hurting you in a way or another it feels like you never knew them in the first place since u couldn’t ever imagine them hurting you!

Of course, I don’t wanna feel better!
 Can you fucking imagine?!

Sometimes people that have been through something that hurt them don’t want to let go because if it feels like if they let go of the pain it will seem nothing was real in the first place. That way pain brings them comfort.

song.embed_content: Read “Cigarette Ahegao” by Penelope Scott on Genius
song.title: Cigarette Ahegao

songs.full_title: Cool Girl Shuffle* by Penelope Scott
songs.title: Cool Girl Shuffle*

annotations: Screwing everything up, and doing everything wrong
might refer to how its harder to get things right if you’re struggling with depression and/or anxiety which makes it harder to get better
UwU
UwU connects to the ahegao, because ahegao faces are most commonly used in anime and manga, looping back around to the online anime, hentai, and manga communities.
(UwU)

UwU and its counterpart OwO and all their deviations are emoticons, not too dissimilar from shrugs (¯_(ツ)/¯ or  ¯_( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)/¯) and smiles ( :), >:D, ;) or any other). UwU and OwO originate from Hentai but are often associated with Furry Culture. UwU and OwO are usually included in furry roleplay or media mocking such things. These emoticons and be inherently sexual or can be just used in everyday speech. UwU represents closed eyes and OwO represents open ones. Both can be written in uppercase (UwU, OwO) or lowercase (uwu, owo).

The use of UwU in this song can also be connected with the usage of the word ahegao and the way the first line is written and spoken. ‘UwU’ is often connected with anime-esque online culture. Talking in a baby voice is often associated with cuteness or anime in general in online communities. People often use ‘w’s to add a childlike effect to a statement as opposed to regular typing. It all connects to the aheago aswell, because aheago faces are most commonly used in anime and manga, looping back around to the online anime, hentai, and manga communities.

Uh huh
 Yeah
The final few notes are reminiscent of the line ‘I feel so used’ from Rät, the closer song to the Public Void album (which this song is the opener to).
As an Amewican, fuck!

Scott is angry that people are using the phrase “as an American” because it is usually followed by someone not understanding why someone else needs something ex. “as an American I don’t know why people complain that we need healthcare when I am healthy.”

God bless this perfect shitstorm
 I hope that it takes me with it
This may refer to the pandemic creating the ‘perfect storm’ for the aforementioned possible eating disorder and other mental health problems, which skyrocketed during lockdown.
Well, I feel better now

This line references another song in the playlist, “Feel Better.” In this song, Scott reiterates the point that “I don’t wanna feel better/No ones ever going to love me like that again.”

In Cigarette Ahegao, it can be inferred that turning to smoking and drugs has made her feel better for the moment and pushed her worries to the side for a second
We covered it in a class that I’m about to fail

This song came out during quarantine when many schools were switching over to online learning, a change that was very difficult for many students. Many students reported having problems paying attention or even caring about school during a global pandemic.
Get fucked on smoke and wine
The nicotine from cigarette smoke can enhance the sensation of being drunk, getting Penelope more fucked up
I hope to have you with me

In the previous line Penelope expresses a desire to leave her situation. This line uses the word “hope” to evoke a sense of half-formed plans and uncertainty, much like the word “someday” above. The “you” in question could be a friend or partner, and the reason for hoping to have them with her is likely the high rate of suicide and/or dying from preventable causes due to lack of insurance.

And it is 85 degrees, I don't know what I need

annotations: I don’t know anything, I don’t even know what I don’t know
the singer is completely lost in life, and is very clueless. they don’t have motivation to learn new things, but state they don’t know anything.
And I’m so tiny and so old,

My personal opinion, Penelope feels she in so insignificant to she feels as unimportant as a bug, referring to the tiny part of this lyric. As for the old part, I don’t have much of an idea but I do think she could mean she doesn’t feel very important or special so maybe she meant out of style like ‘old’ trends, because those have nothing to do with age, but that’s only a guess.
I don’t know what I need
restating that they don’t know what to have to do or want they need to make themself feel better
I don’t know anything, I don’t even know what I don’t know

this is a unique saying instead of saying “ I don’t know anything ” and ending the line the singer said “ I don’t even know what I don’t know” saying I don’t know anything would imply that the singer has not learned anything in there life. say I don’t even know what I don’t know is  letting us know that the singer feels that because they don’t know the things they have not learned yet that they are stupid and  can’t be the protagonist as the last line states
I don’t know what I need

this is  referring to the last lyric “ and I have never been so cold  and it is 85 degrees” that line is saying that they are cool and the has nothing to do with the temperature and “ I don’t know what I need” is referring that the singer has no idea on how  / what they need to make them self feel better / more warm .
The walls are empty, it’s so ugly, I could burn the whole place down
They don’t have any actual interests (in reference to the next one), and they feel gross all the time

Here’s the thing: I can’t do anything right
 Try as I absolutely totally might
An early introduction into the singer’s view of herself that is continuously expressed throughout the song.
You’re already halfway out the door
The person she likes is tired of how sensitive she is and they’re leaving.
My wet heart catches on every thorn
Her heart is so sensitive and fragile that she gets hurt at every inconvenience.
And I’ve never looked so old,
Scott is worried about growing up. By singing that she’s ‘never looked so old’ symbolizes her fears.

description.plain: Self Care by Penelope Scott is all about mocking self care tutorials.. It appears in one of her most recent albums, Hazards (As of the time I am editing this, 22/11/2021).

song.embed_content: Read “Self Care” by Penelope Scott on Genius
song.title: Self Care

body.plain: Self Care by Penelope Scott is all about mocking self care tutorials.. It appears in one of her most recent albums, Hazards (As of the time I am editing this, 22/11/2021).

annotations:
I’m not like that, I’m not coming back
 I don’t want it like that, not like that
 I’m not like that, it won’t be okay
 I don’t want it like that, not that way

In the chorus Penelope Scott makes it clear that her mental state is not one that might be bettered with the coping skills presented in the previous verse.

“I’m not coming back” may refer to the feeling of being lost, or permanently changed by an aggravated mental state. It may also be a simple reproach to “the people in the back row,” mentioned in the second verse, who judge Penelope. A simple “no, thank you.”

The third line, “it won’t be okay,” echoes an ever-present sentiment shared among people suffering from depression – the presumption that nothing will ever change for the better

I’m not like that, I’m not coming back
 I don’t want it like that, not like that
 I’m not like that, it won’t be okay
 I don’t want it like that, not that way

In the chorus Penelope Scott makes it clear that her mental state is not one that might be bettered with the coping skills presented in the first verse.

“I’m not coming back” may refer to the feeling of being lost, or permanently changed by an aggravated mental state. It may also be a simple reproach to vapid advice calling for “self-care,” a simple “no, thank you.”

The third line, “it won’t be okay,” echoes an ever-present sentiment shared among people suffering from depression – the presumption that nothing will ever change for the better

When you’re stressed, when things are just a mess
 When you’re feeling kinda anxious or, like, maybe depressed
 I mean, maybe if you tried more, maybe if you tried

In the pre-chorus Penelope Scott makes it clear what the pieces of advice from the first verse were for – a worsened state of mental health.
She showcases that sometimes those simply might not work when you are in shambles. This is accompanied by a feeling of guilt expressed with the words “maybe if you tried.”

Maybe if you try more, then you would deserve it
 Maybe if you fixed the whole world by yourself, then you’d earn it!

Often, those with mental illness will feel that the reason they haven’t improved is an issue with their character. They don’t deserve help or improvement because they aren’t working hard enough to feel better, or could only possibly deserve to feel better by meeting an unachievable standard.

Do drugs, have sex, tell your deepest darkest secrets to your friends
 Post cringe, buy guns, are you done yet?
 Fuck, not enough, cry a river, smash a cup
 But it’s never ever gonna be enough
 For the people in the back row, but you still choose to listen
 Knowing damn well it’s really not their decision

These are more destructive self care mechanisms, which are in contrast to the first lyrics.

People that are in the back row describes people that aren’t involved in something. So people in the back row could describe people who are coercing Penelope into doing things just for them to watch the destruction.

Top ten ways to smear honey on your face
 Cut your nails, do your makeup, and wake up late
 Fill a bottle up with water and a soggy piece of fruit
 Fill the workbook up with things that you can do

In the opening verse Penelope Scott describes the most popular pieces of advice for when you’re feeling down: doing skin-care routines, taking care of your looks, drinking water, journaling. These are often shown as the “go-to” activities, without any second thoughts, which the author expresses between the first verse and the pre-chorus.
Maybe if you took more vitamins, you would learn to live a fuckin’ life

In the last line of the pre-chorus, Penelope Scott emphasizes the irony hidden within these pieces of “self-care” advice: it is only surface-level and performative, often without addressing the root of the issue. Taking vitamins won’t make you learn how to live a life, yet that’s how some “self-care” articles often try to frame it.
This line is a bite at how such articles are simply pseudoscience, surface-level misinformation, and contribute to those suffering from mental illness not being taken seriously, as a multitude of such articles are aimed at them.

search_results.title: Dead Girls
search_results.lyrics:
Dead Girls Lyrics[Spoken]
"I, your name, do solemnly swear not to off myself, think about offing myself, or continue thinking about offing myself without reaching out for help after listening to this song."

[Verse 1]
Sometimes I see her on the sidewalk, biking on the wet chalk
Spelling out their names, and I feel insane
'Cause I know it's just a game that I'm playing with my brain
I don't see her, but I see her, and I know it isn't real
But I fake it anyway, pull a smile and wave
Nod and look away, wait for it to fade
But it happens all the time, and people say it's fine
My roommate says they're killing us, but we're killing ourselves
And I'm surrounded by
[Chorus]
Dead girls on the road
Dead girls on my phone
Dead girls, where do they go?
All of the fuckin' dead girls all around
Dead girls in my town
Dead girls, I don't know
Dead girls, where do they go?

[Verse 2]
And it'd be wrong to say I miss them, I didn't really know him
I just have a couple friends that say they knew him well
They seem like something special, really don't they all?
I guess before you're gone, it can be kinda hard to tell
I broke the fucking news, it wasn't mine to break
She cried, but I was empty, it wasn't mine to say

[Chorus 2]
There's dead kids on the road
Dead kids in my phone
Dead kids, where do they go?
I wanna be a dead kid, with my friends
Dead kids, home again
Dead kids, I don't know

[Post-Chorus]
You like them better dead, better dead?
Just say you want it like that
You like me better dead, better dead?
Gun against your head, you like them dead
You might also like[Bridge]
And if all you ever see are dead girls
And if all you hear is terrible news
Maybe it's not all about the dead girls
Maybe it's more about you
The living need attention too

[Chorus]
Dead kids all the time
Dead kids in our primes
Dead kids, where do they go?
I wanna be a dead girl, like the rest
Dead girls are the best
That's why we're on every show

[Post-Chorus]
You like them better dead, better dead?
Just say you want it like that
You like me better dead, better dead?
Gun against your head, you like them dead7Embed

body.plain: This is the draft of a song Penelope Scott sang on her Tik Tok page, (@worsethanithot), titled Dead Girls. It is unknown at this time if she’s planning on making and releasing a full version.

annotations: The wet chalk

Possibly a reference to dead bodies' being drawn around with chalk. The rain gets rid of the chalk making it all meaningless anyway, foreshadowing to the bodies on the roads and the people, who only see them, are the ones on the lower moral state.
Dead kids all the time
So many people are killing themselves, that it seems like it happens all the time. it’s almost constant.
I wanna be a dead kid, with my friends
Scott may feel some envy of the treatment dead kids receive after they have passed; being revered and remembered as someone special; she wishes her and her friends could be thought of this way.
She cried, but I was empty, it wasn’t mine to say

It appears Scott had to break the news of a suicide to a friend, and her friend was close with the victim while she was not. Her friend was crying while Scott was okay.

She feels like she did not have the right to break this news as it she wasn’t the one affected by it.
Do solemnly swear not to off myself, think about offing myself, or continue thinking about offing myself without reaching out for help after listening to this song
Scott is speaking to the listener, having them swear and oath that after listening to the song the listener will not commit suicide, and if they are having suicidal thoughts they will seek help.
They seem like something special, really don’t they all?
she is refering to people that have died (by suicide) seem special when they have passed but before no one really pays attention to you

But I fake it anyway, pull a smile and wave
 Nod and look away, wait for it to fade
she fakes knowing that thoese girls arent there she smiles at the dead girls and then looks away
Dead girls, where do they go?

Once they are dead they are well, gone. But where do they go?
Shes wonderin what happened to them, how they died, did they kill themselves?
Did they get buried, did they get thrown in a river to decay?

Dead girls in my town
 Dead girls, I don’t know
People are dead in her town, dead in other towns, dead everywhere.
Dead girls, where do they go?

Once they are dead they are well, gone. But where do they go?
Shes wonderin what happened to them, how they died, did they kill themselves?
Did they get buried, did they get thrown in a river to decay?

description.plain: “American Healthcare” is a song dedicated to all the people who become medical professionals to help others, but who end up feeling overwhelmed by the restrictive American healthcare system that prioritizes profit over people’s health.

song.embed_content: Read “American Healthcare (Glitzy)” by Penelope Scott on Genius
song.title: American Healthcare (Glitzy)

body.plain: “American Healthcare” is a song dedicated to all the people who become medical professionals to help others, but who end up feeling overwhelmed by the restrictive American healthcare system that prioritizes profit over people’s health.

songs.full_title: American Healthcare: Early Draft by Penelope Scott
songs.title: American Healthcare: Early Draft

annotations: [Verse 1]

In the very very beginning of this song, if you listen closely you can hear a random chord similar to the ones at the end of the song. On June 16, 2022 Scott posted a screenshot of a DM she received on her Instagram story. The person was asking what that note was and she revealed she did it by accident because she exported the song on a loop and she always wondered if anyone would notice. She also said if you listen to the song on loop you can hear how the end and beginning are the same chords.
I’ve gotta do
She believes what she’d doing has to be done. It’s not a choice she has to do this to help people, which is her job.
But I fucking helped people
She knows she’s done her job right, even though she isn’t reaping any benefits. She doesn’t understand how she can work so hard and get no reward

They hired me in my hometown
 And then again when I moved away
Implying they follow her wherever she goes and that she can’t escape them

It trickled into both my ears
 It got louder over the years
Likely referencing the way companies may tell people that what they do is right over and over until no one questions them anymore.
I did my best to save the sick

They did everything in their power to help the sick but they still witnessed or are aware of illness/death at the hands of corruption. This is emphasised by the organ sound that starts to play in the background and comes to the forefront after the 2nd chorus, which is reminiscent of funeral music.
I just think they should feel okay while they’re alive

This line is changed from the previous pre-chorus, the word changing from “good” to “okay”. This shows how Scott is giving in and compromising her ideals – she no longer wants people to feel good, she’ll settle for okay. It’s still better than how they feel now.

It was the government
 The companies, bureaucracy
 The congressmen, the lobbyists, and lies
As the healthcare system in America is part of a capitalist system, Scott calls out the people in power for putting themselves before the patients.
I did my best
Scott concluding this song on this lyric exposes the vulnerability of the speaker, they are doubting their own ability to help others. They did their best, but it wasn’t enough. It won’t ever be.

When I was seven years old
 I saw a dead man in the road
 Outside the liquor store a few blocks from my school
 Well he was cold and he was warm
 He looked the damn same as before
 Except for something in the eyes and a bit of drool

This lyric alludes to the sad reality of children being exposed to violence at a young age. The internal confusion of being desensitized to violence but being expected to care for the sick will create problems for those in the healthcare field.

description.plain: “Born2Run” is the first single after her album, Public Void. gained popularity and recognition in May 2020 on tiktok. penelope scott still hadn’t finished the song but she had drafts of Born2Run posted on bandcamp on July 2, 2020. It was not until November 4, 2020 that Born2Run finally published on all digital platforms. And also she posted a draft of the song on soundcloud on November 19, 2020

song.embed_content: Read “Born2Run” by Penelope Scott on Genius
song.title: Born2Run

body.plain: “Born2Run” is the first single after her album, Public Void. gained popularity and recognition in May 2020 on tiktok. penelope scott still hadn’t finished the song but she had drafts of Born2Run posted on bandcamp on July 2, 2020. It was not until November 4, 2020 that Born2Run finally published on all digital platforms. And also she posted a draft of the song on soundcloud on November 19, 2020

songs.full_title: Born2Run (Glitzy, w/ Secret Ending) by Penelope Scott
songs.title: Born2Run (Glitzy, w/ Secret Ending)

annotations:
Drugs and money who’s between your covers
 Wouldn’t matter to me one way or the other

Scott is commenting on how politicians (and politics in general) are just full of scandals. Sex, drugs and money are just the tip of the iceberg. Scott doesn’t care about any of the pulp drama that’s fed into the mainstream.

And when soft boys and their succulents
 And girls dressed to crack skulls
this is referencing some fashion trends in gen-z. the singer belives that gen -z is close to taking the capitol due to unfair changes in the goverment.

And now gun control is a fuckin’ wicked problem
 I don’t know if anybody knows how to solve it
 But if I were in congress and someone shot up a school
 I’d fucking cry about that too
 And so my question is to you
This addresses how school shootings are becoming more and more prevalent, yet congress has yet to pass many major laws to prevent them.
And when  thots and animals storm the capital
This could be a reference to the capital storm on Jan 6, 2021, causing chaos and destruction as Trump Supporters protested the Election.
Paint our shirts
This could be referencing when protesters paint their t-shirts to get across a message at political marches etc.

Are you really gonna save the world like that?
 With  your tits half out on instagram?

This could be referencing the way that many social media stars and celebrities put on a facade, showing their followers how amazing of a person they are and how much of a difference they are making to the world, whereas in reality they are only helping themselves instead of making the difference to the world which they, with all of their money and influence, could very easily make.
Her heart is pure, the math checks out, so whats the move?

This is making the point that ACTIVIST ARE RIGHT but will be roundly ignored by the people with power to change anything. It’s pointing out that she’s right about people suffering, right that we should be upset and trying to stop it, right that she and the people around her were guaranteed rights that they’ve been denied in practice, and asking “if I’m right, what are you going to do about it?” And unfortunately the answer in this song and in real life is NOTHING unless we fight for it and force them to acknowledge our humanity and our god given right to not be brutalized by others our whole lives.
You nixon smile makes me fuckin’ sick
Nixon may refer to Richard Nixon, a former U.S. president. Perhaps whoever this lyric is targeted towards has a smile as… distinct as Nixon’s.
Life and liberty, sometimes property, the right to try to feel good

The sometimes property line refers to the fact that Thomas Jefferson stole the famous opening line of the US Constitution, “life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness” from John Locke, who wrote “life, liberty, and property”. Therefore, sometimes property.

Crying like a kid every single day?
 Hell yeah mother fucker I’m afraid it’s true
 People are in pain, what’s wrong with you?

Here, Penelope is voicing her anger against people telling her to calm down or stop shouting for change. She replies with the fact that that is literally the only moral and empathetic option. People are in pain, so she’ll scream as loud as she has to, and you’re unempathetic for not.

description.plain: Penelope expresses her conflicted feelings towards someone she loves through this song.

song.embed_content: Read “Lavender” by Penelope Scott on Genius
song.title: Lavender

body.plain: Penelope expresses her conflicted feelings towards someone she loves through this song.

songs.full_title: From Russia With Love by Penelope Scott
songs.title: From Russia With Love

annotations: [VERSE 1]
The short piano part at the beginning of the song sounds like the original Tetris theme.

It takes a very special kind of glitch
 To make a monster out of something so quiet
Speaks on how it’s difficult to make a quiet, calm person yell and become extremely angered.

I’m in love
 With a druggard
She’s in love with a druggard. A druggard is someone who is addicted to drugs.

I’m trying my best
 Giving my all
 And yeah it turns out that’s not very much at all
 It turns out that’s not very much at all
She mentions that she thinks her all isn’t good enough.

Well I’ve never really been so very stellar
 At writing songs for things that make me glad
Most of Penelope’s songs are sad, or about her complaining about something or other. Here, she mentions how she isn’t good about writing songs that make her happy.

Best giving my all
 And yeah it turns out that’s not very much at all
In this line, Scott states how demanding relationships can be if they don’t live up to the others expectations and how often it can be draining

Am I really gonna be
 Just someone’s girl?
Although Penelope is scared of her partner leaving, she’s also scared of being defined by the relationship if it carries on.

When I just loved you back if I’ve had the mind
 
 But maybe I don’t

“And I’d just love you back if I had the mind / But maybe I don’t” are the correct lyrics. She wishes that she could simply let go and fall in love, but her inner conflicts are making it difficult to be vulnerable.

What am I gonna do
 When you leave me too?
Using the word “too” adds a lot to this line. It shows that Penelope has had her heart broken before, and can’t stand for it to happen again.

And it comes out sounding like I’m sad
 
 Or maybe I’m mad
 Yelling at the world
 Am I really gonna be a stupid girl?

Penelope has very mixed emotions about her love interest. She’s in love, but is afraid of being “a stupid girl”, meaning that she doesn’t want to just be another girl who fell in love and gave up everything for a boy. Her feminist beliefs are conflicting with her feelings.
